msgSnippet: Hi David, ... I m not sure I understand the question correctly.  The stacktrace in any given thread is available via getStackTrace().   (since 1.5) The Thread
messageBody:
Hi David,

On Jan 27, 2009, at 6:55 PM, David Saff wrote:

> This is unfortunately a frequent request, and well beyond my
> knowledge of
> Java threading. If anyone knows how to find out the current
> stacktrace of a
> separate thread, please let the list know, and we will incorporate
> it in
> JUnit.
>






I'm not sure I understand the question correctly. The stacktrace in
any given
thread is available via getStackTrace(). (since 1.5)

The Thread class has a static method, getAllStackTraces(), that
returns a
map<Thread, StackTraceElement[]> if that works better.

Or is this a question of identifying the correct thread for the trace?

rgds,
cas




>
>
> We could use JDI to run the thread in another JVM, but that seems
> fairly
> high-cost (in terms of compatibility and dependency) for what we'd
> get.
>
> For any particular instance where a test is timing out, running with a
> profiler can often point out the high-cost operations, which is
> usually more
> interesting than the single sample of what the thread was doing at
> the exact
> timeout.
>
> David Saff
